title: How Stew Leonards Jacked a Career Fair

data.content: A business lesson for everyone
https://miro.medium.com/max/6400/1*u7da4EZTOQF18M9dTwjmPw.png
Stew Leonard was running some errands on a weekend evening.
He was a well-known entrepreneur in the area, working in the dairy business. He had just opened his first grocery store.

While walking the aisles of a convenience store, he bumped into the principal of the local elementary school. The principal said, “Why don’t you come out for a career day? I’m sure the kids would love to know about your business.”
Stew declined. He is a humble man. He knows that dairy farming isn’t glamorous. He didn’t want to put the starry-eyed kids to sleep with the subject.
The principal pressed him further, insisting, saying the kids would really love to hear his story.
Being a good sport, he agreed to come in.
The next week, he arrived at the school and a fire truck was planted out in front of the building. He was immediately demoralized knowing he’d have big shadows to stand in.
As he walked down the school hallway, he saw signs in front of each classroom, with different professionals talking to rooms full of smiling kids.
A pilot was talking about flying his jet and all the missions he’d been on. A police officer was discussing fighting crime. A doctor was talking about his life, studies, and treating patients.
Stew would be competing with people who had fast, electric jobs.
Finally, he arrived at his room, where a sign was taped to the wall by his door, “Dairy Farmer.”
In his classroom, there were only a handful of kids, most of whom were the children of his employees. Translation: their parents made them attend.

He went and gave his presentation, discussing life as a dairy farmer, raising and managing cattle, and later opening his first business. Then, later, a second tiny group of kids came in and he did another presentation.
At the end of the day, he was getting ready to leave and he bumped into the principal in the hallway. The principal had a funny look on his face and asked Stew, “What did you do?”
The principal then said, “We’ll need a much bigger room for your next talk. You cleaned out the other rooms. All the kid want to come to your talk now.”
Stew smiled and held up his hand. In it was a bunch of coupons.
At the end of Stew’s talk, he’d given each kid a coupon for free ice cream at his new grocery store.
In doing this, he’d become a rockstar that outshone all the other people at career day. Suddenly, all the kids seemed to have wanted to become dairy farmers.
The kids had left his room and skipped down the hallway, waving their ice cream coupons like a flag to tease their peers.
His story is a simple lesson for you: the power of spontaneous generosity.
If you are promoting, doing anything, providing unexpected add-ons and gifts can make a huge impact on your business and help spread the word-of-mouth advertising.
Remember this acronym: WIIFM It means, “What’s In It For Me”
I say this in the nicest way possible — everyone is always out to get something. It could be a feeling, a physical product, a massage, great information. It’s always something.
Obviously, using free ice cream coupons wouldn’t fill up a room of adults for an hour. And it may not be an economical strategy to scale.
But it should get you thinking about the possibilities that come with free add-ons. Provide value to people and people will give you that window of opportunity.
Today, Stew Leonards has expanded to multiple stores and makes $341 million in annual revenue. They did it in no small part to Stew’s kindness and ability to think on his feet.
And with regret, no, I do not have free ice cream to offer you today. Only an air high five.
